facts.text: Field number 1096 known as Sukhna field recorded in revenue papers in name of Banwari as tenant-in-chief.
In 1949, Banwari mortgaged the plot to Lakhan Singh.
In 1952, field shown under cultivation of Rameshwar (deceased), Ram Sarup (uncle), Jailal (brother), Sita Ram and Saddon; record does not show title under which holding possession.
Defence plea: Possession shown as Banwari's in 1954, 1955, 1956; but entries corrected in 1956 showing possession of Rameshwar and four others, continued in 1957.
On April 18, 1957, Banwari sold field to Tej Singh (appellant); Tej Singh applied for mutation, opposed by deceased Rameshwar and four others shown in possession.

Offence committed on July 27, 1957 at sunrise: Five appellants (Tej Singh father, Mizaji son, Subedar nephew of Tej, Machal cousin, Maiku servant) came armed - Tej Singh with spear, Mizaji with pistol in dhoti fold, others with lathis; brought plough, patela, bullocks.
Disputed field had three portions: sugarcane, jowar sown, rest uncultivated. Maiku started ploughing jowar field, overturning jowar; Tej Singh with spear kept watch.
Bateshwar (PW 7) saw and informed Ram Sarup; Ram Sarup with Rameshwar, Jailal, Israel (unarmed) came to field.
Ram Sarup inquired why Tej Singh damaging field; Tej replied he purchased it. Altercation ensued.
Four accused (Mizaji, Subedar, Machal, Maiku) cutting sugarcane came to Tej Singh; on Tej Singh's instigation, Mizaji fired pistol hitting Rameshwar who fell and died 1 hour later. Accused fled.
Ram Sarup, Jailal, Israel went to police station Nawabgunj; Ram Sarup made FIR at 7:30 a.m. naming all five accused.

Police searched but accused not found; proceedings under ss. 87/88 CrPC initiated but before process, Subedar, Tej Singh, Machal, Maiku appeared August 3, 1957; Mizaji August 14, 1957; taken into custody.
Prosecution relied on eyewitnesses and Bateshwar.
Defence: Total denial of participation; suggested Rameshwar killed in dacoity at Ram Sarup's house.

Sessions Court (Farrukhabad, Sessions Trial No. 61/1957, judgment Nov 28, 1957): Accepted prosecution story, Ram Sarup in possession; appellants unlawful assembly with common object to take forcible possession, prepared to cause death if interfered; convicted all under 302/149 IPC (Mizaji death, others life); 148 IPC (Tej, Mizaji 3 yrs RI), 147 IPC (others 2 yrs RI); sentences concurrent.

Allahabad High Court (Criminal Appeal No. 1809/1957, Referred No. 138/1957, judgment Feb 28, 1958): Confirmed convictions and sentences; appellants unlawful assembly to take forcible possession, prepared for murder; knew murder likely due to weapons; accepted Matadin and Hansram testimony that accused threatened to finish complainants.

legal_issues.text: What was the common object of the unlawful assembly and whether the offence of murder was committed in prosecution of the common object or was such an offence as the members knew was likely to be committed in prosecution of the common object.
Whether other members had knowledge of Mizaji's pistol.
Applicability of s.149 IPC to facts, distinguishing first and second parts.

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court not justified in inferring other members knew of Mizaji's pistol.
Common object only to take forcible possession; murder neither in prosecution of common object nor known likely to be committed.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Queen v. Sabid Ali (1873) 20 W.R. 5 Cr.; Chikkarange Gowda v. State of Mysore AIR 1956 SC 731

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellants went to take possession quietly in absence of complainants, believing land theirs.
Party divided, only Mizaji fired on father's ask; no use of other weapons; hesitancy mitigates death sentence for Mizaji.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellants formed unlawful assembly to take forcible possession, prepared to commit murder if necessary; knew murder likely from weapons and conduct.

court_reasoning.text: Tej Singh knew son Mizaji had pistol; circumstances justify inference others knew.
Common object to take forcible possession undoubted; weapons (spear, pistol, lathis), conduct (gathered, threatened 'finish all', fired on refusal) show prepared to commit murder if necessary.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Evidence of Matadin and Hansram accepted.

court_reasoning.text: First part s.149: Offence committed with view to accomplish common object, connected immediately; no preconcert needed, shared by all.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Murder immediately connected to forcible possession.

court_reasoning.text: Second part s.149: Even if not first part, members knew offence likely ('know' not mere possibility); weapons and conduct point to knowledge.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Heavily armed party to take land/force possession implies likelihood of murder.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguishes Queen v. Sabid Ali: Differing opinions, but each case on facts; here premeditated, not sudden.
Distinguishes Chikkarange Gowda: Special circumstances (composite charge, no notice, findings on chastisement only).
Armed entry despite revenue proceedings implies expectation of opposition; division of party and gathering on protest shows unity.
Mizaji carried pistol for common object, used it; no mitigation in obeying father.

holdings.text: s.149 IPC applies; murder committed in prosecution of common object of forcible possession (first part) and/or members knew likely (second part) from weapons and conduct.
All appellants guilty under s.302 r/w s.149 IPC; Mizaji death sentence proper, others life imprisonment.

precedents_cited.relevance: Interpretation of s.149 IPC; differing judicial opinions on common object and knowledge of likelihood of murder in forcible possession cases; decided on sudden events unlike here.

precedents_cited.case_name: Chikkarange Gowda v. State of Mysore
precedents_cited.relevance: Conviction under 302/149 not justified due to defective charge mixing s.34/149, findings of chastisement only; special circumstances not present here.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Convictions under 302 r/w 149 (murder by unlawful assembly), 148 (rioting armed with deadly weapon), 147 (rioting); analysis of first/second parts of s.149.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals, confirmed High Court judgment upholding Sessions Court convictions and sentences: all under s.302 r/w s.149 IPC (Mizaji death, others life), s.148/147 IPC.

key_quotes.text: "the appellants had gone prepared to commit murder if necessary in the prosecution of their common object of taking forcible possession of the land"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key finding on extent of common object under first part of s.149.

key_quotes.text: "the expression 'I know' does not mean a mere possibility... it is a matter of common knowledge that when... a body of heavily armed men set out to take... land... someone is likely to be killed"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains 'knew likely' under second part of s.149.

key_quotes.text: "when an offence is committed in prosecution of the common object, it would generally be an offence which the members... knew was likely to be committed"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Agrees with Couch CJ in Sabid Ali, but maintains distinction between parts.
